{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3633441,"name":"","username":"AvocadoPeel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avocadopeel/{size}/232401_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-22T18:33:30.316Z","cooked":"

many (all?) of the ctre control reqests have a “UseTimesync” parameter. i understand the use of timesync for status signals, but how exactly does it work for control requests?

all the docs i can find just say “delay applying this control request until a timesync boundary”.

what is a “timesync boundary”? how exactly does it work and what is the use case?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":2,"updated_at":"2025-05-22T18:33:30.316Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":162,"readers_count":161,"score":97.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502244,"topic_slug":"control-request-time-sync","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61239,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/control-request-time-sync/502244/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3633540,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-22T19:02:53.323Z","cooked":"

We’re still working on the software documentation for Control Timesync, but here’s a preliminary explanation.

The primary use case is to use control timesync along with status signal timesync, so let’s assume that SetControl is being called from a thread using WaitForAll() on a CANivore, and devices are Pro-licensed.

By default, control requests are sent periodically by the robot controller (roboRIO) at a fixed rate (often 100 Hz). This is done completely asynchronously from your robot program, which can result in nondeterministic control latency (anywhere from 0-10 ms at 100 Hz). That means that even though your data acquisition has minimal latency due to timesync, your control can have significant and unpredictable latency.

That latency issue is generally fixed by setting the control request UpdateFreqHz to 0. This makes it so control requests are not sent periodically at all, they are instead one-shot whenever you call SetControl. As a result, this minimizes the latency between SetControl and the device applying the new control request. For something like swerve steer motors with onboard PID, minimized latency on the SetControl call is the end goal.

However, the time between each device control application can be inconsistent—it depends on things like complexity of the robot code between WaitForAll and SetControl, garbage collection, or even CAN bus latency. As a result, even with UpdateFreqHz = 0, there is still a small amount of nondeterministic latency between WaitForAll and the following control application. For most use cases (particularly onboard PID), this timing inconsistency doesn’t matter, but there are a few circumstances (such as running PID on the roboRIO) where it can become noticeable.

Control Timesync (alongside UpdateFreqHz = 0) solves that inconsistent timing issue. Rather than applying the control request immediately, the device doesn’t apply the control request until just before it sends its timesync’d status signals. This results in a larger latency between SetControl and the device applying the control, but in exchange you get completely consistent control timing, as well as minimized, constant latency between control application and the following WaitForAll. Because latency is now completely deterministic (it’s basically the timesync period - 1ms), it becomes possible to latency compensate your control requests, making roboRIO PID control more consistent.
